articles.author: OLUWADAMILOLA FASHINA
articles.description:
I remember the first time I was handed log files to separate into system and traffic logs. My eyes glazed over almost instantly. It felt like staring into a cryptic language, and by now you probably know I love that word 'cryptic' because thatâ€™s exactly what it was. These logs looked like digital junk drawers, overflowing with way too much information and barely any of it made sense at first glance.
But the truth behind this log files is that they are secretly telling us everything about our systems: What's broken, what's about to break, and sometimes even who broke it.
In this article, I'm going to show you how can read, filter, visualize, and store this log files. So you can can save the day, impress your colleagues, and maybe even score you that promotion while making impact for both yoâ€¦
articles.title: Logs Donâ€™t Lie: How to Turn Messy Files into Clear Wins for Your Team and Business

articles.author: Dev Cookies
articles.description:
In the world of real-time data processing, Apache Kafka is a powerhouse for messaging and event streaming, while Kafka Streams is a robust tool for processing that data in real time. Theyâ€™re often mentioned together â€” but they arenâ€™t the same.
This blog will give you a complete comparison, dive deep into Kafka Streams architecture, and show how the two can work together to power real-time data pipelines and microservices.
Apache Kafka is a distributed messaging system designed for high-throughput, low-latency, and fault-tolerant event streaming.



Component
Role




Producer
Sends (publishes) messages to Kafka topics


Consumer
Subscribes to topics and consumes messages


Broker
Kafka server that stores and serves data


Topic
A named stream to which data is written and read


Partition
Tâ€¦
articles.title: ğŸ§µ Apache Kafka vs. Kafka Streams: What's the Difference? How Do They Work Together?

articles.description:
In todayâ€™s digital-first world, a website is more than just a digital storefrontâ€”itâ€™s the heart of your brandâ€™s online presence. Whether you're running a startup or an established enterprise, the art and science of modern web design and development are what differentiate thriving businesses from the rest. To truly unlock digital brilliance, it takes more than flashy visuals or functional featuresâ€”it requires a thoughtful balance of creativity, usability, and technical performance.
Letâ€™s explore what makes web design and development in 2025 a blend of innovation, strategy, and craftsmanshipâ€”and why every business should take it seriously.
The Evolving Role of Web Design 
Todayâ€™s users expect personalized, frictionless experiences. This means responsive layouts, fast-loading pages, and mobilâ€¦
articles.title: Unlocking Digital Brilliance: The Art and Science of Modern Web Design & Development

articles.author: Pierce Ashworth
articles.description:
The following article is an overview of the subject: 
In the rapidly changing world of cybersecurity, in which threats are becoming more sophisticated every day, businesses are using artificial intelligence (AI) to strengthen their security. While AI has been part of cybersecurity tools since the beginning of time and has been around for a while, the advent of agentsic AI is heralding a new era in innovative, adaptable and contextually aware security solutions. The article explores the potential for agentsic AI to improve security and focuses on applications to AppSec and AI-powered automated vulnerability fixing. 
Cybersecurity is the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) that is agent-based 
Agentic AI can be which refers to goal-oriented autonomous robots that can detect their environmenâ€¦
articles.title: Agentic AI Revolutionizing Cybersecurity & Application Security

articles.author: achraf bradji
articles.description:
In the world of decentralized finance (DeFi), payment streams are becoming an increasingly popular way to facilitate ongoing, automatic payments. But how do we ensure that users can send and receive payments over time without losing control? Thatâ€™s where the Decentralized Payment Streaming System (DPSS) comes into play.
In this post, Iâ€™ll walk you through an update to my DPSS contract, transforming it from a simple ETH-only stream to a more versatile, secure, and feature-rich version that supports both ETH and ERC20 tokens.
What's Changed in DPSS2?
ERC20 Token Support
The most important update is the support for ERC20 tokens. Initially, the system was limited to ETH. Now, it supports both ETH and any ERC20 token, giving users more flexibility in how they fund and receive payment streams.
Tâ€¦
articles.title: Building and Updating a Decentralized Payment Streaming System (DPSS) â€“ ERC20 Token Support and More

articles.author: Vasanth
articles.description:
Hey Everyone,
I was building a platform pipet.dev which uses AI to write backend logics as per your input/flow requirements & automatically syncs with your GitHub.
This would be helpful in cases where you're clearer with your logics but needs to be go faster with developments & also platform will have auto testing feature which lets you to auto test the API's using AI, which knows about your logics.
I can ensure that pipet platform can make your development to go from 0 to 1 easily & faster.
I have took a video on how it's working. Check it out : Full-Stack Auth with Pipet-Connected Supabase & Lovable!
Needed few people as early tester to give feedback to shape the platform. 
Know your thoughts on comments, happy to invite you for earlier access with free credits.
articles.title: I built an full-Stack Auth by AI platform Pipet.dev Connected to Supabase

articles.author: Shyamala Chandramohan
articles.description:
List 1:
concept 1: 
packages = ["Letter", "Box", "Parcel"]
print(packages)
item=packages[1] #here the index 1 refers to item box.
print(item)

#Output
['Letter', 'Box', 'Parcel']
Box

Concept 2:
packages = ["Letter", "Box", "Parcel"]
print(packages)
#add an item in the list
packages.append("special delivery")
print(packages)

#Output
['Letter', 'Box', 'Parcel']
['Letter', 'Box', 'Parcel', 'special delivery']

Concept 3:
packages = ["Letter", "Box", "Fragile Box", "Parcel", 
"Special Delivery"]
last_package = packages.pop() 
#removes last item in the list
print(packages)
packages.remove("Box") #removes item box
print(packages)

#Output
['Letter', 'Box', 'Fragile Box', 'Parcel']
['Letter', 'Fragile Box', 'Parcel']

Concept 4:
packages = ["Letter", "Box", "Fragile Box", "Parcel"]
position = packages.index("Parcel")
print(position)
packages.sort() # arrange alphabetical order
print(packages)
packages.reverse()
print(packages)

#Output
3
['Box', 'Fragile Box', 'Letter', 'Parcel']
['Parcel', 'Letter', 'Fragile Box', 'Box']
articles.title: Python list

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Adrian Zmudzinski
articles.description:
Cryptocurrency compliance firm Bitrace found that $649 billion worth of stablecoins flowed through addresses classified as high-risk in 2024, according to an April 29 report.
Bitrace defines high-risk blockchain addresses as those used by illegal entities to receive, transfer or store stablecoins.
Crypto compliance firms typically score crypto wallet addresses based on their likelihood of involvement in illicit activities. The higher the risk, the higher the likelihood of foul play, and the less likely compliant crypto businesses are to accept the assets.
Per the report, the amount accounted for roughly 5.14% of all stablecoin transaction volume in 2024. This is down 0.8% from 5.94% the previous year, but significantly higher than the 2.8% reported in 2022 and 1.63% in 2021.
Proportion of â€¦
articles.title: $649B stablecoin transfers linked to illicit activity in 2024: Report

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Sasha Shilina
articles.description:
What is digital identity?            
            
                
Your digital identity is the fingerprint you leave across the internet, a living map of who you are.
Your digital identity is more than just your name or email; it stretches from your social media profiles and crypto wallet addresses to your device fingerprints and even the rhythms of your daily browsing habits. In the fast-moving world of cryptocurrency, where identity and financial access often overlap, digital identity theft isnâ€™t just a nuisance; itâ€™s an open door to your assets.Â 

Without strong protection, even small pieces of stolen information can be stitched into a full profile, giving cybercriminals everything they need to impersonate you, seize your funds or lock you out of your accounts.
What many donâ€™t realizeâ€¦
articles.title: Your digital identity got stolen â€” Now what?

According to a press release shared with Cointelegraph, the integration enables users to trade over 1 million Solana-based tokens directly through the 1inch decentralized application (DApp), benefiting from maximal extractable value-protected swaps, optimized rates and open-source smart contract infrastructure.
The move brings 1inchâ€™s Fusion protocol to Solana for the first time. Fusion enables users to define their ideal swap parameters, which are then executed by competing professional market makers, or â€œresolvers,â€ using Dutch auction mechanics.
Combined with Solanaâ€™s ultra-fast block times, the setup promiseâ€¦
articles.title: 1inch launches on Solana with crosschain swaps in the pipeline

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Helen Partz
articles.description:
The concept of a Russian ruble stablecoin received special attention at a major local crypto event, the Blockchain Forum in Moscow, with key industry executives reflecting on some of the core features a ruble-backed stablecoin might require.
Sergey Mendeleev, founder of the digital settlement exchange Exved and inactive founder of the sanctioned Garantex exchange, put forward seven key criteria for a potential â€œreplica of Tetherâ€ in a keynote at the Blockchain Forum on April 23.
Mendeleev said a potential ruble stablecoin must have untraceable transactions and allow transfers without Know Your Customer (KYC) checks.
However, because one of the criteria also requires the stablecoin to comply with Russian regulations, he expressed skepticism that such a product could emerge soon.
The DAI modâ€¦
articles.title: Russian ruble stablecoin: Exec lists 7 â€˜Tether replicaâ€™ features

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Stephen Katte
articles.description:
A trio of major Abu Dhabi institutions, including the Emirateâ€™s sovereign wealth fund, have teamed up to launch a new dirham-pegged stablecoin.
Abu Dhabiâ€™s sovereign wealth fund ADQ, the United Arab Emiratesâ€™ largest bank, First Abu Dhabi Bank (FAB), and the massive conglomerate the International Holding Company, have partnered to launch the stablecoin, pending regulatory approval, the three companies said on April 28.
The trio said the stablecoin would be regulated by the UAEâ€™s central bank and backed by the countryâ€™s currency, the dirham. It will also support use cases such as machine-to-machine and artificial intelligence.
Source: IHC
The goal is to place the UAE at the â€œforefront of global blockchain innovation,â€ while also strengthening the digital infrastructure, according to ADQ.

articles.title: Abu Dhabi institutional giants team up for dirham stablecoin

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Brayden Lindrea
articles.description:
The founders of the crypto fintech firm Bankera used funds from the projectâ€™s 2018 initial coin offering to purchase luxury properties worldwide, according to a report by the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project.
The OCCRP reported on April 28, citing leaked company records and bank statements, that nearly half of the funds from Bankeraâ€™s 100 million euro ($114 million) ICO were transferred to a bank in the Pacific Island country of Vanuatu that was purchased by the projectâ€™s founders, Vytautas KaraleviÄius, Justas Dobiliauskas and Mantas MockeviÄius.
Soon after, the Vanuatu bank reportedly began issuing millions of euros in loans to companies owned by the trio to build a luxury real estate portfolio â€” including a villa in the French Riviera and high-end property in Lithuania, â€¦
articles.title: Bankera founders used ICO funds on global property buys: Report

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Stephen Katte
articles.description:
Researchers at the University of Zurich have been accused of undertaking an unauthorized four-month-long experiment on a Reddit board using artificial intelligence-generated comments to test whether AI could alter peopleâ€™s opinions.Â 
As part of the experiment, AI-powered accounts faked a variety of personas, including a rape victim, a person opposed to specific social movements and a trauma counselor specializing in abuse, moderators of the r/changemyview subreddit said in an April 26 post.
â€œOur sub is a decidedly human space that rejects undisclosed AI as a core value,â€ the moderators said. â€œPeople do not come here to discuss their views with AI or to be experimented upon.â€Â 
The researchers used AI to generate responses but attempted to personalize the replies based on information from thâ€¦
articles.title: Zurich Uniâ€™s secret AI experiment manipulated Redditorsâ€™ opinions

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Martin Young
articles.description:
US federal prosecutors and the co-founders of the crypto mixer Samourai Wallet have asked a court for more time to consider potentially dismissing the case after the Justice Department rolled back its crypto enforcement.
Lawyers for Samourai Wallet CEO Keonne Rodriguez and chief technology officer William Hill said in an April 28 letter to Manhattan federal judge Richard Berman that they jointly requested with the government â€œfor a continuance of the pretrial motions schedule by 16 days.â€
The Samourai executives' lawyers said on April 10 that they wrote to Acting Manhattan US Attorney Jay Clayton to request the dismissal of the case after an April 7 memo from Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche shuttered the Justice Departmentâ€™s crypto team.
â€œOn April 24, 2025, defense counsel met with thâ€¦
articles.title: Samourai Wallet, feds ask for time to mull dropping crypto mixer case

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Ezra Reguerra
articles.description:
While United States dollar-denominated stablecoins dominate the stablecoin and real-world asset (RWA) tokenization game, other competitors are coming into play, according to Tether co-founder Reeve Collins.Â 
Speaking to Cointelegraph in Dubai, Collins said that while dollar-backed stablecoins may be dominant, other currencies and assets may compete to back stablecoins.
â€œThe stablecoin definitely helps preserve the dollar dominance, especially in the crypto space,â€ Collins said. â€œThe dollar is kind of the reserve currency of crypto. But now there are other currencies coming into play. But more importantly, itâ€™s not currencies. Itâ€™s other types of backing,â€ he added.
Collins said that other assets used to back stablecoins may compete with US dollars by bringing a higher yield to users.Â 
Inteâ€¦
articles.title: US dollar facing growing competition for stablecoin dominance: Tether co-founder

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Brayden Lindrea
articles.description:
Legendary investor Ray Dalio has said the world is â€œon the brinkâ€ of the global monetary order breaking down, which is being accelerated by the Trump administrationâ€™s tariff disruptions.
The trade tensions are fracturing the monetary, political and international world orders by fueling deglobalization and unsustainable trade imbalances, Dalio, the former CEO of hedge fund Bridgewater Associates, said in an April 28 X post.
Dalio added that this is leading to irreversible damage, and an increasing number of importers and exporters, particularly between the US and China, are drastically reducing interdependencies and â€œmaking alternative plans.â€
â€œ[Theyâ€™re] recognizing that whatever happens with tariffs, these problems won't go away, and that radically reduced interdependencies with the US is â€¦
articles.title: Ray Dalio says global monetary order â€˜on the brinkâ€™ of breakdown

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Martin Young
articles.description:
The crypto lobby group, the DeFi Education Fund, has petitioned the Trump administration to end what it claimed was the â€œlawless prosecutionâ€ of open-source software developers, including Roman Storm, a creator of the crypto mixing service Tornado Cash.
In an April 28 letter to White House crypto czar David Sacks, the group urged President Donald Trump â€œto take immediate action to discontinue the Biden-era Department of Justice's lawless campaign to criminalize open-source software development.â€Â 
The letter specifically mentioned the prosecution of Storm, who was charged in August 2023 with helping launder over $1 billion in crypto through Tornado Cash. His trial is still set for July, and his fellow charged co-founder, Roman Semenov, is at large and believed to be in Russia.
The DeFi Educâ€¦
articles.title: Crypto group asks Trump to end prosecution of crypto devs, Roman Storm
